bibl.title: Letter from Alton S. Pope to Laura Armistead Carter, August 1, 1927

div1.p: Pope thanks Laura Carter for Henry Carter's notes. He is impressed that Carter had theorized a living host as an explanation of the extrinsic incubation of yellow fever before this had been proven.

div1.head: Letter from Alton S. Pope to Laura Armistead Carter, August 1, 1927
div1.opener:
DR. ALTON S. POPE
1308 E. 56TH ST.
CHICAGO
August 1, 1927.
Miss Laura A. Carter,
“Dunlora”, Box 453,
Charlottesville, Va.
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
Your most kind letter with enclosure of the
notes on your father's work by Dr. Frost, came to me
Saturday morning. Please accept my most sincere thanks
for your kindness and assistance in this matter. The
notes gave me exactly the information which I wish on
your father's work on yellow fever and with the
references to his published articles will, I am sure,
supply all the desired material for my lectures.

I am having the notes photostated and will re-
turn the original to you promptly as soon as I can have
the copy completed. I am also writing Dr. J. P. Leake
for photostats of your father's original articles as I
would like very much to have them on file.

In view of the most excellent outline which
Dr. Frost has written of your father's work, I feel that
any lecture notes of my own would seem very futile.
As a rule, I lecture from headings, but if I am able to
prepare notes which seem satisfactory, I shall be only
too glad to send you a copy.

Your notes on your father's mention of a living
host as one of the explanations of the phenomena of ex-
trinsic incubation is most illuminating. It would be
impossible for a man of Dr. Carter's type of mind to collect
data on such a subject as yellow fever without trying to
fit it into a general philosophy of the disease and it
is illuminating that he should strike upon the actual
phenomena before it had been proven.
